description: From Middle English terme, borrowed from Old French terme, from Latin terminus (“a bound, boundary, limit, end; in Medieval Latin, also a time, period, word, covenant, etc.”).
Doublet of terminus and termon. Old English had termen, from the same source.

entries.meaning: (medicine, colloquial) Born or delivered at term.
That which limits the extent of anything; limit, extremity, bound, boundary, terminus.
examples: "Alright, look...we can spend the holidays with your parents, but this time it will be on my terms."

entries.meaning: A chronological limitation or restriction, a limited timespan.
examples: The term of a lease agreement is the period of time during which the lease is effective, and may be fixed, periodic, or of indefinite duration.

entries.meaning: Any of the binding conditions or promises in a legal contract.
examples: Be sure to read the terms and conditions before signing.

entries.meaning: Specifically, the conditions in a legal contract that specify the price and also how and when payment must be made.
examples: Q: What are your company's terms? A: Net thirty, cash or check. [This answer means that the net total must be paid within 30 days; see Net D.]
The latest models are available now, on the lowest terms you'll find anywhere, guaranteed.

entries.meaning: (geometry, archaic) A point, line, or superficies that limits.
examples: A line is the term of a superficies, and a superficies is the term of a solid.

entries.meaning: A word or phrase (e.g., noun phrase, verb phrase, open compound), especially one from a specialised area of knowledge; a name for a concept.
examples: "Algorithm" is a term used in computer science.
The noun phrase "red blood cell", the acronym "RBC", and the word "erythrocyte" are synonymous terms.

entries.meaning: Relations among people.
examples: We are on friendly terms with each other.

entries.meaning: Part of a year, especially one of the divisions of an academic year.

definitionGroups.group: Duration of officeholding, or its limit; period in office of fixed length.

entries.meaning: The time during which legal courts are open.
Certain days on which rent is paid.
With respect to a pregnancy, the period during which birth usually happens (approximately 40 weeks from conception).
(of a patent) The maximum period during which the patent can be maintained into force.
(archaic) A menstrual period.
examples: My wife, after the absence of her terms for seven weeks, gave me hopes of her being with child, but on the last day of the year she hath them again.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Any value (variable or constant) or expression separated from another term by a space or an appropriate character, in an overall expression or table.
examples: All the terms of this sum cancel out.
One only term is odd in ( 12; 3; 4 ).

entries.meaning: (logic) The subject or the predicate of a proposition; one of the three component parts of a syllogism, each one of which is used twice.
examples: The subject and predicate of a proposition are, after Aristotle, together called its terms or extremes.

entries.meaning: (astrology) An essential dignity in which unequal segments of every astrological sign have internal rulerships which affect the power and integrity of each planet in a natal chart.
(art) A statue of the upper body, sometimes without the arms, ending in a pillar or pedestal. [from 17th c.]
examples: You have been already informed, I have no doubt, of the subject which we have chosen: the adorning a Term of Hymen with festoons of flowers.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A piece of carved work placed under each end of the taffrail.

verbs.description: term (third-person singular simple present terms, present participle terming, simple past and past participle termed)

entries.meaning: To phrase a certain way; to name or call.
(computing, informal) A computer program that emulates a physical terminal.

description: Short for terminate, termination, terminated employee, etc.

entries.meaning: One whose employment has been terminated

verbs.description: term (third-person singular simple present terms, present participle terming, simple past and past participle termed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To terminate one's employment
